CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 34;No violation of Art. 34;Remainder inadmissible
JUDGES: Ganna Yudkivska;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is currently serving a prison sentence at the Yenakiyeve Town Correctional Colony ( Prison ) No . DATE , GPE ( “ the LOC ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested by the police on suspicion of burglary . According to the applicant , during his detention from CARDINAL to CARDINAL DATE and subsequent interrogations , which took place at the police station , he was subjected to various forms of ill - treatment , the aim of which was to extract a confession for grave crimes , including murder and burglary . The applicant maintained that he had received multiple bruises and abrasions on his head and body and that several ribs and teeth had been broken . The applicant did not have access to a doctor and the alleged injuries were not recorded .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was given access to an official defence lawyer , appointed by the authorities , who continued to represent him until the completion of the proceedings . On DATE the applicant was transferred to the ORG Town Temporary Detention Centre ( “ the Mariupol ITU ” ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred to the ORG . CARDINAL ( “ the ORG GPE ” ) .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , he complained to the prosecutors that he had been ill - treated . His complaint was allegedly rejected as unsubstantiated by the Deputy Prosecutor of GPE on DATE and he did not challenge that decision before the courts . No copy of the decision was submitted to the ORG . The Government did not contest these submissions , though they provided a copy of the letter from ORG of DATE by which ORG had been informed , inter alia , that the applicant had not lodged any complaints with ORG claiming that unlawful investigation methods had been applied in his case ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In the course of his trial the applicant maintained his complaint of ill - treatment . In particular , the applicant alleged that his confession for having committed some of the crimes with which he had been charged had been obtained under duress . In his submissions before the courts the applicant referred to the decision of CARDINAL DATE , indicating where it was to be found in the domestic case file . While ORG of Appeal gave no reply to the applicant 's complaint , ORG , in its decision of DATE ( see below ) , held , in general terms , that there was no evidence that the applicant 's statements had been obtained in an arbitrary manner . The relevant parts of that decision read as follows :

“ ... ORG disagrees with [ his ] conviction , as , in his view , it is harsh , partial and unfair . [ According to him ] the case was heard with the accusatory inclination ; the force was used during [ his ] questioning ; [ he was ] questioned in a misleading manner ; [ and ] he did not organise a [ criminal ] group ...

Having heard the judge - rapporteur , the prosecutor ... having examined the case materials , and having discussed the arguments in the cassation appeals , the panel of judges concluded that the appeals shall not be allowed ...
There is no evidence that the statements of the convicted were obtained in a misleading or in any other unlawful manner .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred to ORG . CARDINAL ( “ the GPE ” ) , where he was held at least until DATE , when he was transferred to ORG in which he is now serving his sentence . During his detention in GPE the applicant requested and subsequently received dental treatment on CARDINAL occasion and he also had his lungs x - rayed and examined in DATE and DATE . He did not request any other medical aid .

According to the applicant , the conditions of his detention in GPE were poor , he was not provided with food of adequate quality and there was a person with mental health problems detained in the same GPE building with him .
CARDINAL . On DATE the pre - trial investigations in the applicant 's case were completed and the case was subsequently referred to ORG .
CARDINAL . According to the applicant , in the course of the court proceedings , he asked for several witnesses to be called and examined on his behalf . He received no reply to his request .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , acting as a court of first instance , found the applicant , together with CARDINAL other persons , guilty of crimes committed in DATE , including several counts of aggravated murder , burglary and sexual intercourse with a minor . The court sentenced the applicant to life imprisonment and confiscated all his property . The court based its judgment on the statements made before it by the defendants and their statements obtained during the pre - trial investigations in which they had confessed to having committed some of the crimes with which they had been charged ; the statements of QUANTITY victims and witnesses heard by the court and the written statements of CARDINAL other victims and witnesses obtained in the course of the pre - trial investigations ; and the reports of CARDINAL experts .
CARDINAL . The applicant 's lawyer and the applicant himself lodged separate appeals in cassation with the same court .
CARDINAL . The lawyer alleged that the first - instance court had erred in the assessment of evidence and had not applied the law correctly in the case .

CARDINAL . The applicant complained that the first - instance court had failed to summon witnesses on his behalf or the expert on whose conclusions the applicant 's conviction of sexual intercourse with a minor had been based . The conclusions concerned the state of sexual development of the victim . In his appeal in cassation the applicant further alleged that the court had refused to take into account his allegations of torture during his detention and subsequent interrogations in DATE and that it had not examined his submissions concerning various procedural violations committed by the authorities in the course of the pre - trial investigations .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG partly amended the judgment of DATE . However , the applicant 's conviction and sentence remained unchanged . ORG found that the judgment had been well - founded and that there had been no procedural irregularities during the investigation or trial . ORG decision was communicated to the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sent his first letter to the ORG and the application form was received on DATE . In support of his application the applicant submitted copies of the court decisions in his criminal case , his lawyer 's appeal in cassation and several letters from the authorities which the applicant had received in reply to his complaints that his conviction had been unlawful .

CARDINAL . In the letters , which the ORG received from the applicant in DATE , he alleged that the staff of GPE had often refused or substantially delayed the dispatch of his letters , including the application form , addressed to the ORG ; that they had refused to provide him with copies of the documents which he had intended to submit to ORG ( the applicant 's complaints and procedural requests made in the course of his trial and the courts ' replies to the applicant 's submissions ) ; and that they had put psychological pressure on the applicant asking him not to complain about the GPE authorities . The applicant maintained that , because of his application to the ORG , he was placed in a cell with a person suffering from the open form of tuberculosis . As a consequence , he was at risk of being infected with this disease .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG invited the ORG to submit factual information with respect to allegations contained in the applicant 's letters to the ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated DATE , the Government informed the ORG that there had been no interference with the applicant 's correspondence . They submitted copies of GPE register of incoming and outgoing correspondence and the applicant 's written statements addressed to ORG , in which he had acknowledged that he had had no complaints against GPE authorities and that his letters had been dispatched without delay .
CARDINAL . In his letters of CARDINAL DATE and DATE the applicant alleged that on CARDINAL DATE the deputy governor of GPE had told him to write such statements .

CARDINAL . In his letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant stated that in DATE , just before his transfer to ORG , an unspecified member of staff of GPE had made threats against him in order to prevent him complaining about the GPE authorities .

CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated DATE , the ORG asked the applicant to submit documentary evidence in respect of his complaints under LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW . In particular , the applicant was invited to submit copies of his complaints made to the national authorities concerning the alleged illtreatment and copies of their replies to such complaints concerning the events of DATE , a copy of his appeal in cassation against the judgment of ORG of DATE and copies of his written requests to have witnesses examined by the latter court on his behalf .

CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated DATE , the applicant asked ORG to send him copies of his appeal in cassation , the reports on his confrontation with QUANTITY police officers who had allegedly illtreated him , his complaint to ORG stating that he intended to submit those copies to the ORG in substantiation of his application and the latter 's reply .
CARDINAL . In its reply of DATE , the court refused to provide copies of the requested documents because the applicant 's request had no basis in domestic law .
CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated DATE , the applicant requested the same court to send him copies of his complaints to that court about the allegedly unlawful investigations in his case .
CARDINAL . The applicant received no reply to his latter request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sent a third letter to the court of appeal , requesting copies of the same documents from his case file . On DATE he received a reply from the deputy president of ORG . In that letter , he was informed that his request had been refused on the ground that , because his conviction had become final , he was entitled to receive copies only of the courts ' decisions in his criminal case . According to the deputy president of that court , no copies of other documents from the case file were allowed to be sent to the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG invited the ORG to submit written observations on the admissibility and merits of the case ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . They were also requested to submit a copy of the applicant 's appeal in cassation and relevant documents concerning his complaints about the alleged ill - treatment to the national authorities , copies of their replies to such complaints , and copies of his written motions to have witnesses on his behalf examined by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government sent to the ORG their observations on the case and copies of the applicant 's appeal in cassation of CARDINAL August CARDINAL together with written amendments to his appeal dated CARDINAL DATE , copies of the applicant 's letters to the president of ORG of DATE requesting copies of documents from his case file , and a copy of the letter from ORG of DATE by which ORG had been informed , inter alia , that the applicant had not lodged any complaints with ORG claiming that unlawful investigation methods had been applied in his case . The ORG 's observations were subsequently forwarded to the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant informed the ORG that he had found a lawyer to represent him in the proceedings before the ORG and asked for legal aid . On DATE the President of the ORG decided that legal aid should be granted to the applicant for his representation before the ORG . The lawyer prepared and submitted observations to the ORG on behalf of the applicant . By a letter of DATE , the applicant informed that he did not wish the lawyer to continue representing him before the ORG .
CARDINAL . LAW of DATE ( repealed on DATE ) provided for the death penalty as an exceptional type of punishment for particularly serious crimes , including aggravated murder .

CARDINAL . By a judgment of DATE , ORG held that the provisions of LAW concerning the death penalty were contrary to LAW . On DATE those provisions were changed by PERSON , the ORG , to the effect that the death penalty was replaced by life imprisonment . Before the changes of CARDINAL DATE , the maximum term of imprisonment under the LAW had been DATE .

CARDINAL . Under LAW of DATE , an accused , a defendant , their defence lawyers or non - legal representatives may familiarise themselves with materials in the criminal case file at various stages of the proceedings until their completion ( Articles CARDINAL , DATE , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL of the Code ) . When studying the case file they are allowed to take notes .

CARDINAL . According to section DATE of LAW of DATE , citizens have the right to ask the authorities to provide them with any official document , whether or not it concerns them , except in cases in which the law limits access to documents . Copies of the requested documents may be given against the payment of a fee ( section CARDINAL of the Act ) .

CARDINAL . Regulations on case processing in courts of appeal and local courts of general jurisdiction , issued by ORG on DATE and DATE ( Order nos . CARDINAL and DATE ) , respectively , provide for a procedure through which persons taking part in court proceedings may familiarise themselves with case files . In particular , case files should be studied at a court 's LOC in the presence of a member of the registry . Copies of documents included in a file , court decisions which have entered into force and written information notes are issued by registry staff upon a written request and against the payment of a court fee . Upon approval by the president or deputy president of a court , a complete case file may be sent by post to those ORG bodies which are entitled by the law to request it .

CARDINAL . The Internal Regulations of Penitentiary Institutions , approved by ORG for the Execution of Sentences on DATE ( Order no . CARDINAL ) , do not allow prisoners to keep any documents , other than copies of judgments in their criminal cases and correspondence concerning their application to ORG , DATE and CARDINAL to the Regulations ) . Further to amendments made to the Regulations on DATE , a prison administration is required to assist prisoners who wish to obtain copies of documents concerning their applications from the ORG bodies . When copies of such documents are received , prisoners should be allowed to keep them and , if appropriate , to join them to their applications to ORG ) . Under amended LAW , prisoners are to be provided with photocopying services against the payment of a fee .

CARDINAL . A comparative survey of national legislation in CARDINAL of the member ORG demonstrates that while there are no specific regulations on prisoners ' access to their case files , other domestic legal provisions can be relied upon by prisoners to make a request for access to such documents . The most common provisions can be found in ORG . This is the case in CARDINAL of the surveyed member GPE , namely , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE . In CARDINAL member GPE , the relevant provisions can be found in Acts on ORG or ORG , as is the case for GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE . In another CARDINAL member GPE , namely , GPE , GPE , the GPE and GPE , ORG provisions provide the best way for a prisoner to request such documents . Finally , in CARDINAL member ORG , GPE , the relevant provisions can also be found in LAW .

CARDINAL . Using CARDINAL or more of these legal provisions , a prisoner , who does not have a person to represent him or her outside the penitentiary institution , may have access to documents in a criminal case file once domestic proceedings have ended , usually by way of a written request to the court for photocopies of the relevant documents to be sent by post , or , as , for instance , in GPE , consultation of the file under supervision in prison . In the majority of the surveyed member GPE , the photocopies of the relevant documents would have to be paid for , although in some member GPE there is provision for an exemption for charges depending on the means of the prisoner ( such as in GPE ) .
CARDINAL . The relevant extract from the Appendix to the Recommendation Rec(CARDINAL)CARDINAL of ORG to member states on ORG , adopted on DATE , reads as follows :
“ ... Legal advice
CARDINAL Prisoners shall have access to , or be allowed to keep in their possession , documents relating to their legal proceedings ... ”

CARDINAL . According to legal commentary contained in the ORG publication of ORG ( DATE , p. CARDINAL ) , Rule CARDINAL is designed to assist prisoners by giving them access to legal documents which concern them . Where for reasons of security and good order it is not acceptable to allow them to keep those documents in their cells , steps should be taken to ensure that they are able to access them during TIME .
